--- title: "2.6 — Classical Macroeconomics & Say's Law Debate — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"} # Meeting Dates *Thursday, October 6, 2022* ::: ## Overview Today we begin by wrapping up Ricardo’s distribution theory, and turn to the first great debate in the history of economics: the (macroeconomic) debate between Ricardo and Malthus over “general gluts” and Say’s law ## Readings ### Required Readings: - Ricardo readings, Malthus *Principles of Political Economy*, Say *A Treatise on Political Economy* in *Reader* - finish Ch.5 "Ricardo and Malthus" in Landreth & Colander - finish Chs.3-4 "Population, Diminishing Returns, and Rent" and "Ricardo's System" in Blaug ### Recommended Readings: - Thornton *An Enquiry into the Nature and Effects of Paper Credit of Great Britain* in *Reader* - [ Safner (2010), “The Duality of Say’s Law: A Restoration of J.B. Say’s Original Intentions”](/files/readings/Safner-2010.pdf) The second paper is my term paper in my undergraduate History of Economic Thought Class (2010) on Say’s Law (so discount appropriately!). The following Wikipedia entries can also provide more background: - [ Say's Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Say%27s_law) - [ Real Bills Doctrine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_bills_doctrine) - [ Henry Thornton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Thornton_(reformer)) - [ British Currency School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Currency_School) - [ Monetary-disequilibrium Theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monetary-disequilibrium_theory) ### Questions to Help Your Reading - Can there be a “general glut,” a surplus (excess supply) in *all* markets at the same time? - What is Say's Law? - What does Malthus think of Say's Law? - What does Ricardo think of Say's Law (and Malthus' response)? ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab. The lower button will allow you to download a PDF version of the slides. ::: callout-tip You can type h to see a special list of viewing options, and type o for an outline view of all the slides. ::: I suggest printing the slides beforehand and using them to take additional notes in class (*not everything* is in the slides)!
